questions.text: A 27-year-old biochemistry graduate student is presenting her findings on enzyme kinetics at a regional conference. She displays a Lineweaver-Burk plot as part of her presentation, highlighting the utility of this type of graph in determining enzyme kinetics constants. She points out the x-intercept and asks her audience to identify what this value corresponds to in terms of Michaelis-Menten kinetics. Which of the following is equal to the x-intercept in a Lineweaver-Burk plot?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. -1/Km

 

Option B.

 

The Lineweaver-Burk plot is a double reciprocal graph of the Michaelis-Menten equation. By plotting 1/V versus 1/[S], a straight line is obtained where the y-intercept is 1/Vmax​ and the x-intercept is −1/Km​. The negative reciprocal of the Michaelis constant (Km) is represented by the x-intercept because the Lineweaver-Burk plot linearizes the hyperbolic curve of the Michaelis-Menten equation, thus allowing for easier calculation of Vmax​ and Km.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Km​: This is incorrect because Km​ itself is not represented by the x-intercept; rather, its negative reciprocal is.

 

Option C. Km​/Vmax​: This option is incorrect. While both Km​ and Vmax​ are parameters of the Michaelis-Menten equation, the ratio Km​/Vmax​ is not represented by the x-intercept in a Lineweaver-Burk plot.

 

Option D. 1/Vmax​: This is incorrect because the y-intercept represents 1/Vmax​, not the x-intercept.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • With “Double Reciprocal Plot” sometimes it is difficult to achieve high substrate concentrations to reach the maximal velocity conditions.
  • So, ½ Vmax or Km is difficult to determine thus experimental data at lower concentrations is plotted as reciprocals a straight line is obtained when extrapolated to get the reciprocal of Km. This is called Lineweaver Burk Plot or Double Reciprocal Plot which can be derived from the Michaelis-Menten equation.
  • If we plot 1/v against 1/[S], it will give a straight-line graph. X intercept is (-1/Km), from which the Km can be calculated.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 80, Vasudevan 9/ed: p 57.

choices.text: Has higher affinity to glucose compared to glucokinase
Has higher Km to glucose compared to glucokinase
Involved in providing glucose to the peripheral tissues
Not involved in glucose storage by the liver

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with hemolytic anemia, and further investigation reveals a deficiency in hexokinase, a key enzyme in the glycolytic pathway, leading to the premature destruction of energy-depleted red blood cells (RBCs). Which of the following statements about hexokinase is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Has higher Km to glucose compared to Glucokinase

 

Option B:

 

Hexokinase has a lower Km for glucose compared to glucokinase, indicating a higher affinity for glucose. A higher Km would suggest a lower affinity, which is not characteristic of hexokinase.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Has higher affinity to glucose compared to Glucokinase.
 

Option C: Involved in providing glucose to the peripheral tissues.

 

Option D: Not involved in glucose storage by the liver

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose to glucose-6-phosphate is converted by either Glucokinase or hexokinase

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 191-192.

questions.text: What is the velocity of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction at the substrate concentration equal to Km?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Half the Vmax          

 

Option D.

 

The Michaelis constant (Km) is the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of the maximum velocity (Vmax). Therefore, at a substrate concentration equal to Km, the velocity (V) of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction is half of Vmax.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Half the substrate concentration: This option is incorrect because Km is not a measure of velocity but rather a specific substrate concentration.

 

Option B. Same as Vmax: This is incorrect. Vmax is reached only when the enzyme is saturated with substrate, which occurs at a substrate concentration much higher than Km.

 

Option C. Quarter the Vmax: This is also incorrect. The definition of Km specifies that the velocity is half of Vmax, not a quarter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SALIENT FEATURES OF Km:

 

  1. Km value is substrate concentration at half-maximal velocity
  2. It denotes that 50% of enzyme molecules are bound with substrate molecules at that particular substrate concentration
  3. Km is independent of enzyme concentration.
  4. Km is the signature of the enzyme.
  5. The affinity of an enzyme towards its substrate is inversely related to the dissociation constant, Kd for the enzyme-substrate complex.
  6. Km denotes the affinity of enzymes for substrates.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 80-82.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the Michaelis-Menten equation accurately?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. V = Vmax X [S] / Km + [S]

 

Explanation: 

 

  • The Michaelis-Menten equation describes the relationship between substrate concentration ([S]) and reaction velocity (Vi) for an enzyme-catalyzed reaction:

 

V= Vmax x S / Km + S

 

Where:

  • V = velocity of Reaction 
    • Vmax = Maximum reaction velocity
    • [S] = Substrate concentration
    • Km = Michaelis constant (substrate concentration at half Vmax)
  • This equation shows that the reaction velocity increases hyperbolically with increasing substrate concentration.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 79.

questions.text: Which of the following kinetic constants is the best measure for expressing the ‘CATALYTIC EFFICIENCY OF AN ENZYME’?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Kcat/Km  

                                 

Option C.

 

  • Catalytic efficiency is used to quantify and compare the efficiency of different enzymes, different substrates for a given enzyme and the efficiency with which an enzyme catalyzes a reaction in the forward and reverse directions.
  • It is usually expressed as the ratio of Kcat divided by Km
  • Enzyme activity is expressed as micromoles of substrate converted to product per minute under specified assay conditions and its modern method of expression is in Katals (kat)
  • One standard unit (or International Unit) of enzyme activity (U) : amount of enzyme that will convert one micromole of substrate per minute per litre of sample and is abbreviated as U/L
  • One Katal (catalytic activity) is defined as the number of mol of substrate transformed per second per litre of sample (Kcat = Vmax divided by the number of active sites).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ka​/Km​: This option is not correct as Ka​ (association constant) is not typically used in the context of enzyme catalysis.

 

Option B. Km​/Kcat​: This is the inverse of the correct answer and would indicate lower efficiency with increasing values, which is contrary to the concept of catalytic efficiency.

 

Option D. Km​/Ka​: Similarly to option b, this ratio would not correctly represent catalytic efficiency as it suggests higher values indicate higher efficiency, which is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The catalytic efficiency of an enzyme is best expressed as the ratio Kcat​/Km​. Kcat​ is the turnover number, which represents the number of substrate molecules converted to product per enzyme molecule per unit time.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: P 80, Lippincott 7/e: P 54

questions.text: A graph is presented depicting enzyme kinetics with and without an inhibitor. The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows two lines intersecting on the y-axis. The line representing enzyme activity with an inhibitor has a different slope than that without an inhibitor, yet both lines intersect at the same point on the y-axis. Based on this information, what type of enzyme inhibition is being represented in this plot?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Competitive

 

Explanation:

 

In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, the y-intercept represents 1/Vmax, and the x-intercept represents −1/Km. In competitive inhibition:

  • The inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding at the active site.
  • This leads to an increase in Km (i.e., substrate affinity appears reduced).
  • However, since high substrate concentrations can outcompete the inhibitor, Vmax remains unchanged.

 

Thus, in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, lines for inhibited and uninhibited enzyme intersect at the y-axis (same Vmax), but have different slopes due to increased Km — exactly as described in the question.

 

Other Options:

  • Option B (Uncompetitive): In uncompetitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, decreasing both Km and Vmax. The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows parallel lines, not intersecting at the y-axis.
  • Option C (Non-competitive): This affects Vmax (lowered) but not Km, and the plot shows lines intersecting on the x-axis, not y.
  • Option D (Suicidal): Irreversible inhibition with no fixed pattern on the Lineweaver-Burk plot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

“In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with substrate for the enzyme’s active site, increasing Km without affecting Vmax. In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, this is seen as lines intersecting on the y-axis.”

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 62.

questions.text: In an enzyme kinetics experiment, a substrate concentration 1000 times the Km value resulted in the conversion of 1% of the substrate into 12 µmol of product in 9 minutes with a certain enzyme amount. In a modified experiment, one-third of the initial enzyme amount is used with double the initial substrate concentration. How long would it take to produce the same amount (12 µmol) of product in the modified experiment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 27 minutes

 Option A.                                                              

  • Zero-Order Reactions. In some reactions, the rate is apparently independent of the substrate concentration. The rates of these zero-order reactions do not vary with increasing nor decreasing substrate concentrations.
  • First-order reaction. : the rate of reaction is directly proportional to the concentration of the substrate
  • Km : Substrate concentration at which the velocity is half maximum
  • Usually reactions follow zero order Kinetics if substrate concentration is > 10 times of Km value. Here substrate concentration is 1000Km which means irrespective of increasing substrate concentration the reaction won’t be affected.
  • First experiment mentions that 12 µmol products are formed in 9 minutes.
  • In the second experiment the enzyme concentration is reduced to 1/3rd. so the time taken to form the same amount of product will be tripled. Thus the answer is 27 minutes

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reaction rate at or near Vmax is less affected by substrate concentration and more by enzyme concentration. Reducing enzyme to one-third decreases the rate to one-third, extending production time for 12 µmol of product to 27 minutes.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 76-79.

questions.text: The enzyme kinetics for competitive inhibition is High Km and lower affinity. Statement is TRUE/ FALSE:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. True

 

In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme leading to lower affinity of the enzyme for its substrate. This means:

  • Km increases because it requires a higher substrate concentration to reach half of Vmax
  • The inhibitor does not affect Vmax because, at high substrate concentrations, the effect of the inhibitor can be overcome.

 

Thus, the statement:

"The enzyme kinetics for competitive inhibition is High Km and lower affinity." is TRUE.

 

Other Options:

  • Option B. False:
    Incorrect, because the hallmark of competitive inhibition is indeed an increase in Km (high Km) and lower affinity of the enzyme for the substrate, while Vmax remains unchanged.
  • Option C. Information Insufficient:
    Incorrect. The question provides enough detail (mentions competitive inhibition and its effect on Km and affinity), so the information is sufficient to answer.
  • Option D. None of the above:
    Incorrect, because Option A is correct.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

  1. Understand Competitive Inhibition:
    • Recognize that in competitive inhibition:
      • Km increases (affinity decreases),
      • Vmax remains unchanged.
  2. Relate Enzyme Kinetics Parameters to Inhibition Types:
    • Competitive: ↑ Km, no change Vmax.
    • Non-competitive: no change Km, ↓ Vmax.
    • Uncompetitive: ↓ Km, ↓ Vmax.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 57.

choices.text: Substrate concentration at maximum velocity
Substrate concentration at half-maximal velocity
Not a characteristic feature of enzymes
A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Michaelis constant (Km)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Substrate concentration at half-maximal velocity

 

Option B.

 

The Michaelis constant (Km) is defined as the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is half of its maximum value (Vmax). It is a fundamental parameter in enzyme kinetics that provides insight into the enzyme's affinity for its substrate; a lower Km value indicates a higher affinity because less substrate is needed to reach half-maximal velocity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Substrate concentration at maximum velocity: This statement is incorrect. The substrate concentration at maximum velocity is not specifically defined by Km, as Vmax is reached at much higher substrate concentrations where all enzyme active sites are saturated.

Option C. Not a characteristic feature of enzymes: This statement is incorrect. Km is indeed a characteristic feature of enzymes and is crucial in the study of enzyme kinetics.

 

Option D. A low Km value indicates a weak affinity of the enzyme for enzyme-substrate complex formation: This statement is incorrect. A low Km value actually indicates a high affinity of the enzyme for its substrate, as it means the enzyme can achieve half-maximal velocity at a lower substrate concentration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salient features of Km:

 

  1. Km value is substrate concentration (expressed in moles/L) at half-maximal velocity.
  2. It denotes that 50% of enzyme molecules are bound with substrate molecules at that particular substrate concentration.
  3. It is independent of enzyme concentration.
  4. It is the signature of the enzyme. Km value is thus a constant for an enzyme and it is the characteristic feature of a particular enzyme for a specific substrate.
  5. The affinity of an enzyme towards its substrate is inversely connected to the dissociation constant, Kd for the enzyme-substrate complex.
  6. Km denotes the affinity of enzymes for substrates. So, less the numerical value of Km, the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate is more.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 57.

questions.text: Double Reciprocal Plot can be derived from the Michaelis-Menten equation. Choose an appropriate response.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. True

 

Explanation:

 

  • Lineweaver Burk Plot: A graphical representation of 1/V on y axis and 1/S on x axis is called Lineweaver Burk Plot or Double Reciprocal plot.
  • In Lineweaver burk Plot
    • X intercept is –1/Km
    • Y intercept is Km/Vmax
    • Slope is Km/Vmax                

                  

 

Lineweaver-Burk equation

 

  • Dixon Plot: Alternative to Lineweaver Burk Plot. 1/V is measured at different concentration of inhibitor [I], but at same substrate concentration[S].

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Double Reciprocal Plot, or Lineweaver-Burk plot, is indeed derived from the Michaelis-Menten equation.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 57.

choices.text: Competitive inhibitors increase both Km and the Vmax
Competitive inhibitors increase the Km and have no effect on the Vmax.
Competitive inhibitors decrease both Km and Vmax
Competitive inhibitors have no effect on the Km and decrease the Vmax.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female patient with a history of abnormal lipid levels is prescribed statins to manage her condition. Statins act as competitive inhibitors of the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, a key player in cholesterol biosynthesis. Considering the mechanism of action of statins, which statement accurately reflects the effect of competitive inhibitors on enzyme kinetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Competitive inhibitors increases the Km and no effect on the Vmax

 

Option B:

 

  • Competitive inhibitors:  increase in the apparent Km and the inhibition can be reversed by adding additional substrate, the Vmax is unchanged.
  • Non-competitive inhibitors: decrease the apparent Vmax and have no effect on Km.

 

      

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibitors compete with the substrate for binding to the active site of an enzyme, which can be overcome by increasing the concentration of the substrate. Therefore, competitive inhibitors increase the Km (indicating a lower affinity of the enzyme for the substrate due to the presence of the inhibitor) but do not affect the Vmax (maximum rate of the reaction when the enzyme is fully saturated with substrate).

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 82-83.

questions.text: During a practical session, students are tasked with investigating the factors influencing enzyme-catalyzed reactions. One group decides to conduct an experiment with an excess of substrate to ensure it's not the limiting factor in reaction velocity. They aim to identify which factor the reaction velocity would then be directly proportional to under these conditions. What does the velocity of an enzymatic reaction primarily depend on when substrate concentration is not limiting?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Concentration of enzymes

 

Option C.

 

  • When sufficient substrate is present, then the rate of a reaction or velocity (V) is directly proportional to the enzyme concentration.

 

 

  • Velocity of reaction increases proportionately with the concentration of enzyme, provided substrate concentration is unlimited.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Substrate concentration: When the substrate concentration is increased, the velocity is also correspondingly increased in the initial phases; but the curve flattens afterwards.

 

Option B. Effect of temperature: The velocity of reaction increases when temperature of the medium is increased → reaches a maximum → then falls (Bell shaped curve). The temperature at which the maximum amount of the substrate is getting converted to the product per unit time is known as optimum temperature.

 

Option D. Effect of pH: Each enzyme has an optimum pH, on both sides of which the velocity is drastically reduced. The graph formed is a bell shaped curve. The pH decides the charge on the amino acid residues at the active site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

With an excess of substrate, the reaction velocity becomes directly proportional to the enzyme concentration. In this state, every enzyme molecule has the potential to be in constant use, catalyzing substrates into products, thus making the enzyme concentration the primary determinant of reaction velocity.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 56.

choices.text: An activator of the enzyme

questions.text: A kinetic analysis of the effect of a drug on an enzyme's activity was performed and the results shown below were obtained. The drug would be best classified as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A non-competitive inhibitor

 

Option B.

 

  • Analysis of the data indicates that, in the presence of the inhibitor, the Km of the enzyme is the same as in the absence of the inhibitor, but the Vmax is significantly reduced (the extrapolated lines intersect on the x-axis).
  • These features are the hallmark of non-competitive inhibition.
  • The inhibitor binds to a site distinct from the substrate binding site and alters the protein's conformation such that activity is reduced, but not substrate binding.
  • The basic concept behind this question is critical for an understanding of how drugs alter enzyme activities (the basis for pharmacology).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A competitive inhibitor: This would demonstrate an increased Km, but an unaltered Vmax (line intersection on the y-axis).

 

Option C. An uncompetitive inhibitor: This inhibitor alters both the Km and Vmax such that parallel lines are seen on double-reciprocal plots.

 

Option D. An activator of the enzyme: Activation of the enzyme would either decrease the Km or increase the Vmax or both.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows that the presence of the drug increases the slope of the line without changing the x-intercept, which suggests that the Vmax of the reaction is decreased while the Km remains unchanged. This pattern is indicative of non-competitive inhibition, where the inhibitor binds to the enzyme at a site other than the active site and inhibits the enzyme regardless of the substrate concentration.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 59.

questions.text: Which of the following factors affecting enzyme activity will give the graph mentioned?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Enzyme concentration

 

Option A.

 

  • When sufficient substrate is present, then the rate of a reaction or velocity (V) is directly proportional to the enzyme concentration.
  • Velocity of reaction increases proportionately with the concentration of enzyme, provided substrate concentration is unlimited.

 

Explanation

 

Option B. Substrate concentration: When the substrate concentration is increased, the velocity is also correspondingly increased in the initial phases; but the curve flattens afterwards.

 

 

Option C. Effect of temperature: The velocity of reaction increases when temperature of the medium is increased → reaches a maximum → then falls (Bell shaped curve). The temperature at which the maximum amount of the substrate is getting converted to the product per unit time is known as optimum temperature.

 

 

Option D. Effect of pH: Each enzyme has an optimum pH, on both sides of which the velocity is drastically reduced. The graph formed is a bell shaped curve. The pH decides the charge on the amino acid residues at the active site.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A linear increase in reaction velocity with enzyme concentration, indicating a direct relationship under conditions where substrate is plentiful and temperature and pH are stable. In contrast, substrate concentration and enzyme activity typically exhibit a hyperbolic and bell-shaped curve with reaction velocity, respectively, while temperature has an optimal point beyond which enzyme activity decreases.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 56.
